title.value: Automated Detection of Anatomical Landmarks During Colonoscopy Using a Deep Learning Model
title.justification: The title explicitly states the focus of the research on using a deep learning model for automated detection during colonoscopy.
title.quote: Automated Detection of Anatomical Landmarks During Colonoscopy Using a Deep Learning Model

extractions.description: The paper focuses on developing a deep convolutional neural network (DCNN) to detect anatomical landmarks such as the ileocecal valve (ICV) and appendiceal orifice (AO) during colonoscopy, aiming to improve colonoscopy reporting quality.

type.justification: The paper involves the collection and analysis of data from colonoscopy procedures to train, validate, and test a deep learning model, which is characteristic of empirical research.
type.quote: We prospectively collected annotated full-length colonoscopy videos of 318 patients undergoing outpatient colonoscopies.

name.justification: The research deals with the application of deep learning to process and analyze images from colonoscopies, falling under the broader category of medical imaging.
name.quote: This enables automatic detection of anatomical structures during live endoscopies.

name.justification: The focus of the research is specifically on colonoscopy, a type of endoscopy, highlighting its application in this sub-field.
name.quote: Colonoscopy is a key component of effective colorectal cancer (CRC) prevention programs.

name.justification: The paper discusses using AI, specifically deep learning, to assist in medical procedures, which places it within this sub-field.
name.quote: Recent advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) and the development of the deep convolutional neural network (DCNN) allow for real-time image processing during colonoscopy.

name.justification: The paper's central focus is the development and application of a DCNN model for differentiating anatomical landmarks during colonoscopy.
name.quote: We aimed to develop and test a deep convolutional neural network (DCNN) model that can automatically identify ICV and AO.

is_contributed.justification: The paper describes the development of the DCNN model as part of the research's contributions.
is_contributed.quote: A DCNN classification model was developed, validated, and tested in separate data sets.

is_executed.justification: The paper includes results from executing the model on validation and test datasets.
is_executed.quote: Results: After training and validation, the DCNN model could identify both AO and ICV in 18 out of 21 patients (85.7%).

is_compared.justification: The paper does not provide explicit information about comparing this model with other models.
is_compared.quote: We aimed to develop and test a deep convolutional neural network (DCNN) model that can automatically identify ICV and AO.

referenced_paper_title.value: Automated Detection of Anatomical Landmarks During Colonoscopy Using a Deep Learning Model
referenced_paper_title.justification: The research paper itself appears to be the primary source for the model, indicating self-reference.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Automated Detection of Anatomical Landmarks During Colonoscopy Using a Deep Learning Model

name.justification: The dataset was specifically collected and used for training and validating the DCNN model within the study.
name.quote: We prospectively collected annotated full-length colonoscopy videos of 318 patients undergoing outpatient colonoscopies.

referenced_paper_title.value: Automated Detection of Anatomical Landmarks During Colonoscopy Using a Deep Learning Model
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset was used exclusively within the context of the current research study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We prospectively collected annotated full-length colonoscopy videos of 318 patients undergoing outpatient colonoscopies.

name.justification: ImageNet is referenced as a pre-training dataset for the DCNN used in the study, highlighting its role in transfer learning.
name.quote: The DCNN model used in the current study is an off-the-shelf network based on the Inception V3 architecture and pretrained on the ImageNet data set.

referenced_paper_title.value: Imagenet: A Large-Scale Hierarchical Image Database
referenced_paper_title.justification: The ImageNet dataset is widely recognized from its foundational paper, which serves as the primary reference.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Imagenet: A Large-Scale Hierarchical Image Database.
